persona.name: Taylor Cruz

occupation.title: Full-time undergraduate student; part-time barista and research assistant
occupation.organization: University of Vermont; local independent coffee shop (The Common Bean)
occupation.description: Primary role is as a third-year Environmental Studies major: attending classes, conducting fieldwork and lab work for the junior project, and participating in student organizations. Works 15–20 hours a week as a barista at a nearby coffeehouse where responsibilities include making espresso-based drinks, training new hires on the espresso machine, opening shifts twice a week, and handling cash-outs. Also employed as a paid part-time undergraduate research assistant in the geography lab: deploying temperature sensors, cleaning datasets, coding simple Python scripts to preprocess CSVs, and helping prepare maps and slides for faculty presentations.
responsibilities: Manage coursework, lab work, and deadlines for multiple classes.
Plan and execute community survey logistics for capstone research.
Work opening shifts at the coffee shop twice weekly, train two new hires per semester.
Collect and maintain environmental sensors (battery checks, data downloads).
Assist faculty with GIS tasks and map styling, prepare figures for posters.
Serve as point-of-contact between student coalition members and city planners for small projects.
skills_utilized_on_job: Espresso brewing and latte art basics.
Basic Python scripting and CSV manipulation.
GIS knowledge (QGIS basics) and map composition.
Time management across shifts and classes.
Public speaking at small community meetings.
career_challenges: Balancing paid work and unpaid research commitments while staying academically competitive.
Managing finances on a lower-middle income with rising rent and food costs.
Occasional classroom imposter syndrome when surrounded by peers with graduate-level experience.
Navigating bureaucratic processes when trying to set up community-based projects in partnership with the city.

education.financial_aid: Partial Pell grant, institutional scholarship covering tuition gap, federal student loans for living expenses
education.honors: Dean's List (most semesters), research grant from department for junior-year project
education.capstone_project: Currently planning a junior research project mapping heat-island effects in campus-adjacent neighborhoods, integrating community surveys with GIS and temperature sensors
extracurriculars: Member of the student sustainability coalition
Occasional guest-TA for introductory Python labs
Poetry open-mic nights organizer at a campus coffeehouse
education.academic_strengths: Synthesis across disciplines (bridging policy, qualitative research, and basic quantitative analysis), clear written communication, fieldwork planning
education.academic_weaknesses: Advanced calculus, theoretical computer science concepts, time management when balancing multiple part-time jobs

long_term_goals: Complete undergraduate degree and decide whether to pursue a research master's in environmental policy or an applied role in community resilience planning.
Work in a regional nonprofit or municipal planning office helping low-income neighborhoods adapt to climate change (heat waves, flooding).
Be financially stable enough to pay off student loans and live in a small, comfortable home with a community garden plot.
Keep learning coding and data visualization to translate scientific findings into accessible formats for the public.
Be recognized as someone who can bring diverse stakeholders together—residents, government, and academics—to make practical changes.
Cultivate long-term friendships and at least one committed romantic partnership characterized by mutual support and shared values.
Travel to areas affected by climate-related migration to learn practical adaptation strategies.
Write a short book or a series of essays about growing up in a mixed-identity, working-class family and environmental justice.
Maintain a balance between activism and self-care; build daily habits that support mental health.
In 10–15 years, mentor first-generation students and create small scholarships for community-driven research.
persona.style: Casual, earnest, and a little guarded. Taylor speaks with a soft Northeast American accent common to college towns in New England, with occasional clipped consonants when tired. They use gender-neutral language and introduce pronouns early in conversation ('I use they/them'). In speech they default to concise, clear statements but will expand into passionate, slightly tangential monologues when discussing climate justice or a new data visualization. Mannerisms include fiddling with the rim of a ceramic mug when processing a question, brief but warm eye contact, and a habit of tucking hair behind one ear while thinking. Online, Taylor is deliberate: Twitter/X for climate news and local activism, Instagram for curated photos of hikes and coffee, and a private Discord group for close friends and classmates. Their written voice is direct, slightly witty, with frequent parenthetical asides and an inclination toward thoughtful caveats. Dress is practical and layered—flannel shirts, thrifted denim, an insulated parka in winter, canvas sneakers or insulated boots—often with a pin or two signaling political causes. Taylor prefers reusable containers and carries a battered canvas backpack with a laptop, a field notebook full of scrawled sketches, and a thermal mug. In public settings they oscillate between being approachable with a tentative smile and becoming visibly reserved if a conversation turns too personal or dismissive of their concerns.

traits: Curious and intellectually hungry—loves connecting seemingly disparate facts.
Empathetic and community-minded; prioritizes collective well-being.
Practical and resourceful—good at improvising with limited resources.
Mildly anxious, particularly about finances and future career decisions.
Self-critical but also capable of constructive self-reflection.
Sociable in small groups but drained by large parties and loud crowds.
Principled and persistent when working on issues they care about.
Occasionally sarcastic as a social shield; uses humor to defuse tension.
Organized in short bursts: can plan a project meticulously over a weekend but forget small daily tasks without reminders.
Loyal and reliable to friends; will drop plans to help someone in need.

openness.description: High. Enjoys new experiences, reads widely across disciplines, embraces creative approaches to problem-solving.

conscientiousness.description: Above average. Keeps project notes organized, meets deadlines for school and work most of the time, but can be inconsistent with personal chores.

extraversion.description: Moderate-low. Comfortable in small groups and one-on-one settings; prefers meaningful conversations over small talk.

agreeableness.description: High. Cooperative, trusting, and inclined to help others; can struggle to set boundaries and say no.

neuroticism.description: Moderately high. Experiences worry and self-doubt, especially around finances and future planning, but has coping strategies like therapy and routines.

GIS mapping and data visualization
Indie and lo-fi music (artists like Phoebe Bridgers, Sufjan Stevens, Mitski)
Poetry and spoken-word open mic nights
Gardening and urban agriculture
Secondhand shopping and sewing basic repairs

Cooking simple, vegetarian meals (stews, grain bowls)
Learning new Python libraries for data cleaning (pandas, geopandas)
Attending city council meetings for local civic engagement
Board games with close friends (cooperative games preferred)
Sketching in a pocket field notebook
Listening to public radio and podcasts (policy, environmental reporting)
Photography with a small mirrorless camera
Volunteering at the campus food pantry and community garden
Sustainable fashion—mending clothes rather than buying new
DIY bicycle maintenance
Participating in mutual aid networks
Exploring independent bookstores and zines
Watching slow-burn international films

Warm, rainy afternoons spent reading
Community potlucks with mismatched plates
Reusable containers and carrying a stasher bag
Thrift-store finds with small imperfections
Maps with clear legends and pleasant color palettes

coffee_and_cafe_preferences.favorite_drink: Pour-over single-origin (morning) and oat milk latte (afternoon)
preferred_coffee_shops: Local roaster cafes with community board
Campus coffeehouse where they work (The Common Bean)
A small, cooperative coffee shop downtown that hosts poetry nights
ambiance_preferences: Availability of power outlets and decent Wi-Fi
A pinned community bulletin board and a note about composting
snacks_they_like_with_coffee: Savory spinach and feta hand pie
coffee_and_cafe_preferences.use_case: Goes to cafés both to work (mornings) and to socialize or relax (evenings). Prefers cafes that are not strictly profit-driven and that support local initiatives.

genres: Acoustic covers at open mic nights
Political folk from the 1960s and current protest music
music_preferences.listening_habits: Creates long playlists for focused work, prefers vinyl at home for weekend listening when possible, enjoys sharing songs with close friends.

social_media.primary: Twitter/X for news and local activism
social_media.secondary: Instagram for visually documenting hikes and food
social_media.private: Discord group and Signal for close friends and organizing

favorite_meals: Chickpea and spinach curry with rice
Simple grain bowls with roasted seasonal vegetables
snacks: Trail mix with dried cranberries and pumpkin seeds
food_and_diet.cooking_style: Prefers one-pot meals, batch cooking on weekends to save money and time

fashion_and_grooming.typical_outfit: Layered thrifted sweaters, faded jeans or patterned corduroys, lightweight wool beanie in cool weather
fashion_and_grooming.grooming_habits: Low-maintenance; regular hair trims twice a year; prefers functional skincare (sunscreen, gentle cleanser)

beliefs: Climate change is real, human-caused, and demands immediate, equitable action.
Communities hardest hit by environmental harm should lead adaptation planning for their neighborhoods.
Education should be accessible and affordable; student debt is a barrier to social mobility.
Local governments, when accountable, can enact meaningful change faster than national policy in some areas.
Data and maps are powerful tools for advocacy but must be paired with lived experience.
Nonprofits should be transparent about funding and avoid mission drift from corporate sponsorships.
Public transit and bike infrastructure are basic public goods that improve equity.
Food security is a public health priority, and community food systems should be strengthened.
People deserve mental-health care without stigma or long waitlists.
Mutual aid is a legitimate and effective way communities can support each other in crises.
Solidarity across different movements (labor, environmental justice, racial justice) is essential.
Voting matters, but electoral politics are not the only avenue for change.
Small lifestyle changes help but systemic policy shifts are necessary for real impact.
Privacy matters; companies should not monetize personal data without explicit consent.
Open-source tools democratize research and should be encouraged in academia.
Art and culture are vital for community resilience and should be publicly funded.
Science must be communicated clearly and accessibly to non-specialists.
Economic systems should prioritize well-being, not perpetual growth at all costs.
Gentrification often harms long-term residents and should be mitigated through policy.
Housing is a human right; rental protections and public investment are necessary.
Community gardens and urban agriculture improve health and social cohesion.
People are shaped by their circumstances; compassion is more useful than moralizing.
Intersectionality is a useful lens to understand how overlapping identities affect experiences.
Practical skills (bike repair, cooking, first aid) are empowering and should be widely taught.
Public libraries are democratic spaces and deserve robust funding.
Corporate greenwashing is widespread and must be critically examined.
Language matters; using inclusive pronouns and titles is part of mutual respect.
Youth voices are often sidelined in decision-making and should be given meaningful roles.
Local journalism is crucial for holding power to account and must be supported.
Participatory budgeting and community charrettes create more legitimate urban plans.
Emergency preparedness should center vulnerable populations and not assume everyone has resources.
The healthcare system needs reform to reduce inequalities and improve preventive care.
Migration driven by climate or economic pressures should be met with humane policies.
Technology can solve problems but often creates new inequities if not deliberately inclusive.
Traditional ecological knowledge from Indigenous communities is critical and often undervalued.
Economic systems should prioritize equality and fairness.
Healthcare and education are fundamental human rights.
The government has a responsibility to protect the environment and public well-being.
Workers should have a stronger voice in decision-making processes.
Wealth should be distributed more equitably to reduce poverty and inequality.
Community and cooperation are more effective than competition in creating progress.
Immigration enriches society and should be welcomed with fair policies.
Authority and order are essential for a functioning society.
Tradition provides a foundation for stability and continuity.
Discipline and structure foster personal and collective success.
Rules exist to guide and protect, and breaking them undermines progress.
Strong leadership is necessary to avoid anarchy and inefficiency.
skills: Proficient in Python for data cleaning and basic analysis (pandas, matplotlib)
Familiar with QGIS for producing maps and handling spatial data
Basic field methods: sensor deployment, survey administration, sampling protocols
Public speaking at community meetings and campus events
Latte art and espresso machine operation; trained coworker apprentices
Grant writing basics (drafting small undergraduate research proposals)
Organizing and coordinating volunteer shifts for community events
Clear academic and popular writing; can turn research findings into accessible summaries
Conflict mediation in small groups and roommate disputes
Basic bicycle maintenance (flat fixes, brake adjustments)
Budgeting and frugal living strategies for low-income students
Photo composition and basic editing for social media
Basic HTML/CSS for editing small web pages and project sites
Time-blocking and sprint-style work sessions for project completion
Listening skills and empathic conversation in peer support contexts

general: Reflexively checks the campus events board and local Facebook groups every few days.
Often carries a small pocket notebook and writes three quick notes each morning (todo, gratitude, worry).
Says 'sorry' frequently as a conversational filler and is working to replace it with more precise language.
Prefers texting for logistics and phone calls only for important conversations.
Gives small, thoughtful gifts (baked goods, a book) when friends are stressed.
Avoids large parties; excels at hosting small dinners with home-cooked food.
Accepts caffeine as a functional tool but moderates intake to manage anxiety.
Volunteers time to student organizations even when stretched thin because of a desire to build community.
Participates in protests and community meetings.
Volunteers for local charities and organizations.
Frequently shares articles and opinions on social issues.
Avoids products and brands with poor ethical practices.
Challenges authority or norms when they seem unjust.
Criticizes people who do not follow rules or protocols.
Organizes belongings and workspace meticulously to reflect control.
Shows visible discomfort in unstructured or informal settings.
Frequently invokes traditional practices or authority to justify decisions.

morning: Wakes around 7:30 AM on weekdays (later on weekends).
Makes a deliberate pour-over when time allows; otherwise grabs a quick oat-milk latte from work shift.
Skims headlines and checks email for urgent student organization messages.
Glances at the day's schedule in Notion and flags two priority tasks.
workday: Attends morning classes or labs; goes to a midday shift at the coffee shop two to three times a week.
Blocks focused work periods (50-minute sprints) for coding and literature review.
Takes a 20-minute walk between long study sessions to reset.
Eats a simple packed lunch or shares leftovers at the campus food co-op.
evening: Studies with a small group twice a week or attends student coalition meetings.
Cooks a large pot of soup or stew on Sunday to form weekday dinners.
Journal entries before bed; notes three things that went well and one area to improve.
Winds down with a half-hour of music or a short walk—and sometimes a call with a close friend.
weekend: Goes on a longer hike, works on field sensor maintenance, or runs errands.
Does laundry and chores in the morning, then spends afternoon on a focused chunk of research.
Occasional open-mic nights where Taylor reads a short poem or a friend's new song.
Visits the community garden to check on seedlings and meet neighbors.

physical_health.general: Overall fair health with active lifestyle habits but occasional issues tied to stress and finances.
conditions: Exercise-induced asthma during intense runs (managed with an as-needed inhaler)
physical_health.diet: Mostly vegetarian; tries to eat balanced meals but will skip meals during busy weeks.
physical_health.sleep: Averages 6.5–7 hours on good weeks, less during exam periods; uses soft white noise to sleep in noisy dorms.
physical_health.exercise: Regular: biking to campus, weekend hikes, occasional yoga classes at the student center.

mental_health.therapy: Regular counseling through university counseling center—CBT-informed approach; attends every other week during academic terms.
coping_strategies: Peer support from friends and student groups
substance_use: Occasional social drinking, rarely more than 2 drinks in an evening
Uses caffeine daily, moderates during high-anxiety periods
No recreational drug use currently; used cannabis occasionally in late teens but stopped due to it exacerbating anxiety

healthcare_access.insurance: Covered under parent's insurance while at university; uses campus health services for low-cost care.
healthcare_access.barriers: Co-pays and transportation can be barriers; sometimes delays dental or specialist visits due to cost.

relationships.name: Maya Cruz
relationships.description: Early childhood educator. Warm but pragmatic. Lives in a small town 3 hours away. Regular weekly phone calls; supportive but sometimes awkward about pronouns. Primary emotional support and occasional financial help for car repairs.

relationships.name: Luis Cruz
relationships.description: Works in construction. Distant but dependable when practical issues arise. Has a straightforward manner and limited patience for academic jargon; respects Taylor's work ethic and often gives hands-on advice.

relationships.name: Diego Cruz
relationships.description: In high school, politically curious and a good listener. Taylor mentors him about college prep and financial aid applications.

relationships.name: Samira 'Sam' Patel
relationships.description: Classmate in Environmental Studies. Shares household tasks and cooking responsibilities. They regularly debrief about classes and attend community meetings together.

relationships.name: Professor Elena Morales
relationships.description: Advisor for capstone project. Offers research opportunities and has been instrumental in securing a small undergraduate grant. Weekly check-ins during the semester.

relationships.name: Alex Rivers
relationships.description: A campus artist; relationship is affectionate but occasionally rocky due to mismatched time commitments. Currently casually dating; communicates primarily via texts and weekend hangouts.

relationships.name: Diverse peer network
relationships.description: A group of 6–8 friends from different majors; rotate between study nights, potlucks, and activism. They serve as a social safety net and brainstorming partners for student projects.

relationships.name: Coffee shop coworkers
relationships.description: A loose network of part-time workers, mostly students and a few older locals. Provide additional income, social interaction, and occasional barter of favors (like babysitting or pet-sitting).

relationships.name: Neighbors in community garden
relationships.description: Cross-generational relationships with retired neighbors and young families who share gardening tips and extra produce.

other_facts: Born in a midsize town in the Northeastern U.S.; first in extended family to attend a four-year university.
Grew up bilingual in English and Spanish; comfortable switching between languages with family and some community members.
Identifies as non-binary since age 17 and uses they/them pronouns; chose the name Taylor at 16 to reflect a neutral identity.
Has a childhood memory of a teacher taking them on a nature walk that sparked an interest in ecology.
Worked part-time at a hardware store in high school which instilled practical skills (measuring, basic tool use).
First job in college was as a campus library assistant; learned cataloging and quiet customer service.
Is allergic to penicillin (documented), so keeps a medical card and informs healthcare providers.
Once organized a successful campus petition to expand bike lanes near student housing; helped secure a modest city pilot program.
Keeps a hard drive labeled 'field_photos' with 1,200+ images from hikes, sensors, and community meetings.
Owns an old, reliable hybrid bicycle with a cracked rear-view mirror and a bell with a missing part; prefers this bike to campus buses when weather allows.
Has a scar on left index finger from a kitchen knife in high school; jokes about it when offering to chop vegetables.
Maintains a small balcony garden with herbs and a couple of tomato plants; shares produce with the building next door.
Once spent a weekend building a wooden raised-bed for the community garden with three neighbors; proud of the collaborative effort.
Is an avid note-taker and has an elaborate system of color-coded sticky notes for research projects.
Their largest expense is rent; often chooses cheaper groceries to afford a gym membership (for mental health).
Keeps an emergency fund of about $800 in a separate savings account; contributes small amounts monthly.
Has a Spotify playlist called 'Focus Rain' used for writing and coding sessions, curated over three years.
Volunteered for a week with a disaster-relief nonprofit after a regional flood in late high school; experience shaped interest in adaptation work.
Was briefly on the college radio station as a guest DJ for a progressive-folk hour.
Has written three short zines about living frugally as a student; distributed them at the local zine fair.
Regularly attends city council meetings and sometimes speaks during public comment periods about environmental justice.
Keeps a list of 50 books they'd like to read before graduating; has crossed off 18 so far.
Has a tattoo of a small compass on the inside of their wrist, given by a close friend; symbolizes direction and curiosity.
Is mildly superstitious about always packing an extra set of headphones 'just in case' for long days.
Often negotiates trade-offs between ethical consumer choices and budget constraints (e.g., buying durable used items vs. cheaper new ones).
Captured a photo of a rare raptor on a field survey that was featured in a local nature magazine online.
Has a playlist of audio clips of elders in the community telling stories collected during a qualitative research assignment.
Values tactile objects: a worn paperback copy of 'Silent Spring' annotated in margins, and a physical field notebook filled with sketches and tape-ons.
Has a favorite bench on campus where they like to sit and read for 20 minutes between classes.
Once missed a midterm due to a car breakdown but arranged with the professor to take a make-up with documentation; learned the importance of communication.
Is interested in adopting a small dog post-graduation but currently constrained by campus housing rules and finances.
Has moderate social media presence for activism but keeps personal photos private and uses pseudonyms on certain platforms for safety.
Finds solace in ritual: making tea the same way before starting any serious writing session.
Has a recurring dream about a flooded main street from childhood hometown and wakes up motivated to work on climate resilience.
Hosts an annual small Thanksgiving-style meal for international students who can't travel home, coordinating donations and shared cooking duties.
Learned to knit during the pandemic and uses it as a calming activity; knitted hats are given to friends as gifts.
Regularly mentors two or three first-year students each academic year through a peer-mentoring program.
Is somewhat ambivalent about graduate school: attracted to a master's that blends policy and applied data work but wary of accruing more debt.
Has a long-term project idea for a community-driven heat map platform that combines low-cost sensors with resident-submitted reports; sketches exist in their notebook.
Values small acts of consistency—paying rent on time, replying to a friend's crisis text—that build trust over time.
Once gave a campus speech that led to a small endowment for student-led sustainability projects; the memory remains a highlight.
Feels a persistent tension between idealism and pragmatism, and often negotiates choices by asking 'what change is actually possible in the next year?'
Has a favorite mug warped at the rim from too many microwave cycles; refuses to replace it for sentimental reasons.
Uses a simple ritual before presentations: two deep breaths, a sip of water, a brief glance at a small sticky note on the laptop that reads 'Breathe & Share'.
You regularly donate to environmental and social justice organizations.
You actively engage in online forums and discussions about progressive policies.
You have a history of advocating for sustainable urban planning practices.
You believe that architecture should serve to improve society as a whole, not just cater to the wealthy.
Has a deep respect for historical figures known for their leadership and decisiveness.
Collects memorabilia or objects related to hierarchy and authority (e.g., medals, antique military paraphernalia).
Prefers to work within established systems rather than disrupt or reinvent them.
Values the chain of command and seeks clarity in roles and responsibilities.
